title: How to Have Energy to Do Chores when You Are Sick

steps.headline: List the chores you need to complete.
steps.description: Take a moment to think about what needs attention around the house. Write those things down. Take a second look at your list and whittle it down to the things that must be done first. Remember that it's important for you to rest in order for your body to make a quick recovery, so don't plan to overexert yourself.

steps.headline: Do what makes you feel energized before starting your chore list.
steps.description: You may feel as though washing your face or taking a shower reminds you of morning time, and your body responds to that feeling with increased energy. Maybe it’s a game of chess. Do what makes you feel rejuvenated.

steps.headline: Complete chores in five minute bursts when you’re feeling your best.
steps.description: Consider which chores require the least amount of effort. It feels great to complete many of these tasks in a short time. You might be surprised when you realize how many tasks you can complete in only a few minutes. Keep a trash bag on hand so that you don't have to walk back and forth to a trash can. Tackle tasks such as these, which can be done in around five minutes: cleaning the kitchen counter, loading the dishwasher, sweeping the floor, wiping the mirrors, and folding your clothes.

steps.headline: Take a break if you're feeling exhausted.
steps.description: Taking breaks for as long as you need before continuing your chores will sustain your energy throughout the day. Remember that you won't be able to perform the way you would at your healthiest, so don't try to give it your all. It's better to complete your chosen tasks well enough than to spend all of your energy on a single task.

steps.headline: Call a friend.
steps.description: Energy can come from the bonds you share with others. Even a brief chat with a friend or relative who understands your illness can fill you with positive energy. After exchanging a few good vibes, unleash that energy onto your chore list. Find a nearby area outdoors with a comfortable seat while talking to your friend. You may find the fresh air to be invigorating.

steps.headline: Invite a friend over for motivation.
steps.description: Maybe there's a friend or someone else you know has a positive effect on your energy. Let them know that they make you feel energized, and how important they are to you because of it. Invite them over and ask them to provide you with a few positive words of motivation.

steps.headline: Delegate tasks to others.
steps.description: Don’t hesitate to let someone know that you need help around the house. There are probably more people in your orbit than you’re aware of who would enjoy visiting you while knocking out a few tasks. Ask for help directly. Many people prefer to be asked for help, as opposed to feeling as though they must go out on a limb to ask you if they can be of assistance.

steps.headline: Shorten your chore list if necessary.
steps.description: Remember that it isn’t crucial to finish every single task you set out to do in the beginning. When you feel as though you’ve done what you’re able to, cross out everything you’ve done on your chore list and be proud of yourself.

steps.headline: Be positive, and don't beat yourself up.
steps.description: There’s a lot of work to be done around the house. Don’t take it to heart if your energy level doesn’t match up with the tasks at hand. Save those tasks for another day.

steps.headline: Rest often.
steps.description: Take it easy. Reading your favorite books or listening to music you love can provide you with energy to get back up later. If it doesn’t, then that’s okay too. This includes getting plenty of sleep—more than eight hours if necessary.
